user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGetIdByName(osal_id_t *sem_id, const char *sem_name)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_name);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, sem_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGetIdByName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_MAX_API_NAME 20
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_INVALID_POINTER (-2)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The fragments NOT listed above do not need investigation for Rule 21.17 because they do not perform string operations or pass character-buffer pointers into string.h functions: - OS_MutSemGetIdByName wrapper code other than the sem_name usage simply forwards parameters and returns the result; it does not itself call any <string.h> functions. - OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id) and uses of sem_id are not string buffers; they validate/hold an object id (osal_id_t) and therefore cannot cause string.h out-of-bounds access. - Token handling and ID assignment (e.g. *object_id = token.obj_id; OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token); OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish) operate on IDs/tokens and do not manipulate C strings or buffers. - Definitions such as typedef uint32 osal_id_t and the error/code macros/constants do not involve string handling. The selected fragments focus on places where a const char * name is validated, its length is constrained, and then passed through search/match callbacks (including the cast to void*). These are the code locations that must be inspected to ensure any use of standard string functions cannot access beyond the referenced object bounds.
